{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient's symptoms and the presence of gram-positive cocci in clusters on wound culture suggest a Staphylococcus aureus infection, which is a common cause of surgical site infections. The patient's lack of improvement despite appropriate antibiotic therapy suggests that the organism is resistant to the prescribed antibiotic. The most common mechanism of resistance in S. aureus is the production of β-lactamase, an enzyme that cleaves the β-lactam ring of certain antibiotics, rendering them ineffective. This mechanism of resistance is common in penicillin-resistant S. aureus and is increasingly seen in methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) as well. Therefore, the ability to cleave β-lactam rings is the characteristic of the infecting organism that best explains the failure to improve with antibiotic therapy.", "answer_choice": "B"}
